title: Apple Car poaching killed electric motorcycle start-up, says CEO | Trusted Reviews
description:
![Apple
Campus](https://ksassets.timeincuk.net/wp/uploads/sites/54/2017/07/trusted-
reviews-placeholder-3.svg)

**Apple entering a new market is great for competition, but what if it’s at
the expense of start-ups?**

An electric motorcycle company was left floundering after Apple poached a
number of its employees, a new report claims.

According to [Reuters](http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/10/19/us-apple-
motorcycle-idUSKCN0SD0ND20151019), Mission Motors ceased operations back in
May after losing its top talent to the [Apple
Car](https://www.trustedreviews.com/news/apple-car-news-rumours-driverless-
price-release-date-electric) project.

The company, known for its sleek electric bikes that were often compared to
Tesla’s cars, saw a number of engineers leave to begin work with Apple’s
prospective efforts in the electric vehicle space.

“Some close to Mission Motors said it had reached a point of no return by last
fall, when departures to Apple, and other companies, accelerated after a long
struggle to find funding and a sound business model,” reads the report.

“Mission had a great group of engineers, specifically electric drive
expertise,” said Derek Kaufman, former Chief Executive of the firm.

Kaufman added: “Apple knew that – they wanted it, and they went and got it.”

According to the ex-boss, Apple recruiters “began circling Mission” as it was
trying to raise funding last autumn.

It’s reported that an investor who had committed to the funding round backed
out after two key engineers jumped ship to Apple.

This isn’t the first time that Apple has been accused of aggressive poaching
to further its alleged vehicle manufacturing operations.

Back in February, A123 Systems, an electric car battery maker, sued [Apple for
recruiting several top engineers](https://www.trustedreviews.com/news/apple-
car-rumours-continue-as-company-reportedly-poaches-battery-specialists) from
the firm. The companies eventually settled, but the terms were never disclosed
publicly.

Tesla has also reportedly lost a number of its engineers to Apple, which
company CEO Elon Musk has previously made light of.

“Important engineers? They have hired people we’ve fired,” [said Musk,
speaking about Apple](https://www.trustedreviews.com/news/elon-musk-apple-
hires-tesla-rejects) earlier this month. “We always jokingly call Apple the
‘Tesla Graveyard’. If you don’t make it at Tesla, you go work at Apple. I’m
not kidding.”

At the time, Musk cautioned that “cars are very complex compared to phones or
smartwatches”.

He added: “For Apple, the car is the next logical thing to finally offer a
significant innovation”, and said that “a new pencil or a bigger iPad alone
were not relevant enough”.

**Related:[Apple Car: The biggest challenges Apple
faces](https://www.trustedreviews.com/opinions/apple-car-features)**

Earlier today, we reported on new analyst estimations that put the [Apple  
  
Car’s eventual retail price at
$55,000](https://www.trustedreviews.com/news/apple-car-price-cost-analysts),
with 200,000 units expected to  
  
ship in the first year.

In spite of mounting evidence however, Apple is still publicly silent
regarding its oft-rumoured move into the electric vehicles space.

It’s expected that if Apple does release an electric vehicle, it won’t arrive
until at least 2020.

Do you think Apple is poaching employees too aggressively? Let us know in the
comments.
